author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Sunday: ‘Mucho Mucho Amor’ and ‘Snowpiercer’
description: Watch Netflix’s documentary on the astrologer Walter Mercado, and the two-part finale of “Snowpiercer.”
content: MUCHO MUCHO AMOR: THE LEGEND OF WALTER MERCADO (2020) Stream on Netflix. Made in the months before his death, this documentary chronicles the larger-than-life existence of the Puerto Rican television and radio astrologer, Walter Mercado. Mercado became an icon — for his elaborate costumes, focus on positivity and as a gender nonconforming entertainer — and his show was broadcast to millions of viewers every day, until he somewhat mysteriously disappeared from public view. But the directors Cristina Costantini and Kareem Tabsch were able to sit down with Mercado, as well as Lin-Manuel Miranda, the actor Eugenio Derbez and the television host Raúl de Molina to discuss the entertainer’s life and legacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Cook to nourish yourself and those around you.
content: Good morning. I remember Sundays before all this happened, the chores-and-errands giddiness of them, all the menu planning for the week to come, the slow slide into an afternoon of cooking things in advance or cooking just to cook. It was pleasurable labor, so different from the grind of the workweek, and if my inbox was any indication, it was a joy I shared with many of you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Mydans
title: Rex Robles, Plotter of Philippine Coups, Is Dead at 77
description: He was seen as the chief theorist and propaganda expert of a group of ambitious military officers who worked to oust two presidents.
content: Rex Robles, a prominent member of a clique of Philippine military officers who plotted several coups in the 1980s against two presidents, Ferdinand Marcos and his successor, Corazon Aquino, died on July 5 in Manila. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Bonnie Lucas, Still Playing With Dolls
description: The artist finds pleasure and healing in cutting up toys and feminine things, and reassembling the pieces.
content: For the past 41 years, Bonnie Lucas, a Syracuse native who graduated from Wellesley College in the same class as Hillary Clinton, has been making intense, memorable collages of dolls, toys and craft implements at home in her tiny NoLIta walk-up. The collages, often bubble gum pink, are powered by a painful ambivalence toward conventional notions of sex and femininity, as well as political rage. Ms. Lucas prides herself on working without glue, instead pinning, tying, or sewing the collages together, or embedding their constituent parts in clay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Former U.S.A. Gymnastics Coach Faces 14 Charges of Lewdness With a Minor
description: Terry Gray, who had been a coach for the U.S.A. Gymnastics women’s national team, was arrested on Friday, the police said.
content: A former coach for U.S.A. Gymnastics was arrested in Las Vegas on Friday and faces more than a dozen counts of lewdness with a minor, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Who Was That Masked Man?
description: President Trump finally wore a face mask to visit Walter Reed. It was weirdly anticlimactic.
content: In the end, the most surprising aspect of President Donald J. Trump’s decision to finally, months after his own advisers recommended it, bow to medical wisdom and wear a face mask was not that he did it at all — even in his alternate reality, where we are winning against the virus, that was probably inevitable — but the mask that he chose.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Puerto Rico Presidential Democratic Primary Election Results 2020
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Two Ex-Players Sue N.F.L. and Union Over Cuts in Disability Payments
description: The N.F.L. and the players association agreed in a new labor deal in March to reduce payments to 400 former players who cannot work.
content: Two former N.F.L. players have sued the league, the players’ union and the medical board those institutions jointly control for agreeing to reduce the disability payments they received for life by tens of thousands of dollars a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Trump’s Health Officials Warn More Will Die as Covid Cases Rise
description: They struck a sober note on Sunday’s news programs, strongly urging the vast majority of people in hard-hit cities and states to wear masks and avoid large gatherings.
content: Two of the Trump administration’s top health officials acknowledged Sunday that the country is facing a very serious situation with the onslaught of rising coronavirus cases in several states, striking a far more sober tone than President Trump at this stage of the pandemic in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Chatham Hedge Fund Has the Winning Bid for McClatchy Newspapers
description: The family-owned publisher of The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald announced the winner of its bankruptcy sale: Chatham Asset Management, the owner of The National Enquirer.
content: After years of declines in revenue and print circulation, the McClatchy Company, one of the largest and most respected news publishers in the country, announced on Sunday that it expected to be bought by Chatham Asset Management, a New Jersey hedge fund, at the conclusion of a bankruptcy auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Outspoken Chinese Professor Is Said to Be Released From Detention
description: Xu Zhangrun, a law professor in Beijing known for criticizing the Communist Party, was allowed to go home after being detained a week ago, people familiar with him said.
content: An outspoken Chinese law professor who has denounced the Communist Party’s harsh policies under Xi Jinping was released from detention on Sunday, a week after the police took him away, two people familiar with the professor said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Chatham Hedge Fund Has the Winning Bid for McClatchy Newspapers
description: The family-owned publisher of The Sacramento Bee and The Miami Herald announced the winner of its bankruptcy sale: Chatham Asset Management, the owner of The National Enquirer.
content: After years of declines in revenue and print circulation, the McClatchy Company, one of the largest and most respected news publishers in the country, announced on Sunday that it expected to be bought by Chatham Asset Management, a New Jersey hedge fund, at the conclusion of a bankruptcy auction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gillian R. Brassil
title: For Sports Halted at the Outbreak’s Onset, Loans Saved Staff
description: A youth gymnastics organization. Community-based skeet shooters. A freshly formed lacrosse league. These are some of the organizations that received Paycheck Protection Program funds.
content: Tom Brady’s company got one. Mayweather Promotions, the advertising agency founded by the boxing champion Floyd Mayweather, did too. And the Los Angeles Lakers, the eighth-richest sports franchise in the world, got one before returning it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Live Music Returns to the Shore: ‘It’s Like Getting Your Life Back’
description: With the music venues of the Jersey Shore shut because of the coronavirus, Southside Johnny and the Asbury Jukes staged a drive-in concert.
content: OCEANPORT, N.J. — On a hot, humid summer Saturday night down the Jersey Shore, about 1,000 cars parked in a vast lot, seeking some semblance of normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: Trump Aides Undercut Fauci as He Raises Alarm
description: Florida set a single-day U.S. record with over 15,000 new cases. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos pushes for U.S. schools to reopen.
content: President Trump’s advisers undercut the nation’s top infectious disease expert, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, over the weekend, anonymously providing details to various news outlets about statements he had made early in the outbreak that they said were inaccurate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Draper
title: ESPN Suspends N.B.A. Reporter for Vulgar Reply to Senator
description: Adrian Wojnarowski, who is known for his “Woj bombs” of breaking news, emailed a different kind to a U.S. senator.
content: ESPN’s most prominent basketball reporter has been suspended for a two-word vulgar email reply to the office of a United States senator on Friday morning in response to the senator’s critical statements about the N.B.A.’s relationship with China.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 12, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, July 12, 2020
content: The Big City column on Page 3 about socially conservative voters in the Bronx misspells the given name of the state director of the Working Families Party in New York. She is Sochie Nnaemeka, not Soiche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Flower on a Tree
description: Erik Agard plays games with us.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — I hope everyone had a great weekend. The constructor Erik Agard returns to begin our solving week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Emily Cochrane
title: Health Care Takes Center Stage in Battle for Congress During Pandemic
description: As the Trump administration pushes forward on dismantling the Affordable Care Act, Democrats are pressing their advantage on an issue that is becoming a chief focus of campaign advertising.
content: WASHINGTON — In his two newest campaign advertisements, Gov. Steve Bullock of Montana portrays himself as a health care savior, featuring local nurses who say his expansion of public health insurance rescued Montanans and their hospitals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman
title: As India Struggles With Coronavirus, Bollywood’s Biggest Star Tests Positive
description: Amitabh Bachchan, whose face is everywhere in the country, checked into a hospital with mild symptoms. His son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter have also become infected.
content: NEW DELHI — When this country’s biggest film star, Amitabh Bachchan, announced Saturday night that he had contracted the coronavirus, a loud alarm bell rang across India.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: While America Looks Away, Autocrats Crack Down on Digital News Sites
description: Independent journalism is on the defensive, from Hungary to Malaysia.
content: Like many American media types, I spent a lot of time last week reading heated arguments about free speech. I was wondering if I, too, could count myself as a “veteran of the Twitter wars” when Steven Gan distracted me by telling me about his car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Gray
title: Trump vs. the Women Who Lead Michigan: A Battle With 2020 Implications
description: The president has picked fights with Michigan’s governor, attorney general and secretary of state over voting rights and the coronavirus. They haven’t backed down.
content: LANSING, Mich. — Beyond being the women leading Michigan’s state government, Gretchen Whitmer, Dana Nessel and Jocelyn Benson have a lot in common.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk and Marc Santora
title: Poland’s Presidential Election Too Close to Call
description: President Andrzej Duda leads a conservative government that has fought to control courts and the news media while stoking fear of gay people and foreigners. He was challenged by the liberal mayor of Warsaw.
content: WARSAW — Poland’s presidential election, widely viewed as the most important since the end of Communist rule in 1989, failed to produce a clear winner on Sunday night, though final exit polls showed President Andrzej Duda leading the challenger, Rafal Trzaskowski.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Beach City in Texas Once Was Safe Haven but Is Now a Hot Spot
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, July 12, 2020.
content: “I never thought in my wildest dreams that I’d be telling tourists, ‘Don’t come to our beaches.’”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Decameron Project’
description: A series of short stories written in this moment, for this moment.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cancel the Jefferson Memorial?
description: Readers are divided on the merits and flaws of a founding father.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: American Horror, Starring Donald Trump
description: The coronavirus pandemic is spiraling out of control, largely because of the president himself.
content: I think I echo many Americans, and people of the world in general, when I say that I’m having a hard time fully grappling with the gravity of this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Perry Mason’ Season 1, Episode 4 Recap:
description: Perry had it pretty easy this week, but others in his orbit were forced to follow darker paths.
content: There’s a new victim in the Charlie Dodson murder case: his mother’s lawyer. In a concluding scene that colors everything that’s gone before it, this episode of “Perry Mason” ends with the apparent suicide of the debonair defense attorney E.B. Jonathan. (I say “apparent” only because we haven’t yet seen a dead body; years of prestige-television watching have taught me not to count my chickens before they’ve died on-screen.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas London
title: Trump’s Shocking Inaction on Russia
description: Neglecting aggression by Vladimir Putin inevitably invites more of it.
content: Did President Trump know about U.S. intelligence community assessments that the Russians had offered bounties to the Taliban for attacks against U.S. and coalition forces in Afghanistan? He hasn’t so far offered a direct answer but instead shifting, manipulative responses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Senior
title: Dear Liberal Arts Students, You Haven’t Been Robbed
description: The world needs you. Here’s your chance.
content: Over the last few weeks, America’s elite colleges and universities have been announcing their reopening strategies one by one, weighing explicit health imperatives against implicit economic ones. Most have landed on a disappointing-but-realistic conclusion: The fall semester of 2020 will have to involve an alloy of in-person and remote learning. Many college students will experience only an attenuated version of campus life — if they get to experience it at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller
title: 2 Police Officers Are Shot and Killed in McAllen, Texas
description: The officers were responding to a domestic disturbance call when a man opened fire on them, the authorities said. That man later took his own life.
content: Two police officers were fatally shot on Saturday by a man who later killed himself after they responded to a domestic disturbance call in McAllen, Texas, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas London
title: Trump’s Shocking Inaction on Russia
description: Neglecting aggression by Vladimir Putin inevitably invites more of it.
content: Did President Trump know about U.S. intelligence community assessments that the Russians had offered bounties to the Taliban for attacks against U.S. and coalition forces in Afghanistan? He hasn’t so far offered a direct answer but instead shifting, manipulative responses.

Most have landed on a disappointing-but-realistic conclusion: The fall semester of 2020 will have to involve an alloy of in-person and remote learning. Many college students will experience only an attenuated version of campus life — if they get to experience it at all.

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Russia May Ease Oil Production Cuts
description: As lockdowns ease, the Saudis and their allies see room to increase their output. But the spread of the virus “is casting a shadow” over their plans.
content: Saudi Arabia, the world’s largest oil exporter, and other major oil-producing countries are likely to increase their output in August, as coronavirus lockdowns ease and demand begins to rise again.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cancel the Jefferson Memorial?
description: Readers are divided on the merits and flaws of a founding father.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: American Horror, Starring Donald Trump

content: I think I echo many Americans, and people of the world in general, when I say that I’m having a hard time fully grappling with the gravity of this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Flegenheimer
title: What Donald Trump’s ‘Access Hollywood’ Weekend Says About 2020
description: On a Friday, the world heard vulgar audio of Mr. Trump boasting about forcing himself on women. By Sunday night, the episode that was supposed to doom him had begun to recede.
content: Donald J. Trump, down and unwilling to get out, saw only one way back up: Go lower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Rick Rojas and Sheri Fink
title: Florida Records Nation’s One-Day Peak for New Virus Cases
description: The state recorded 15,300 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, easily passing the previous one-day high of 12,274 set at the height of the outbreak in New York in April.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — Florida on Sunday reported the highest single-day total of new coronavirus cases by any state since the start of the pandemic, with more than 15,000 new infections, eclipsing the previous high of 12,274 recorded in New York on April 4 amid the worst of its outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Sarah Mervosh
title: Pittsburgh Seemed Like a Virus Success Story. Now Cases Are Surging.
description: Pittsburgh, a sister city to Wuhan, China, saw only modest cases for months. In the last two weeks, cases are suddenly soaring.
content: PITTSBURGH — A little more than three weeks ago, officials in Pittsburgh announced a milestone enviable for almost any major city in America: A day had gone by without a single new confirmed case of the coronavirus. It was good news for a city that had seen only a modest outbreak all along, even as the virus raged through places like Philadelphia and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Ja’Ron Smith’s Balancing Act: A Black Republican Navigates the Trump White House
description: As a congressional staff member, Mr. Smith once wore a hoodie in a demonstration on Capitol Hill protesting the death of Trayvon Martin. Now President Trump calls him “my star.”
content: WASHINGTON — In the days after Trayvon Martin was shot and killed by a white neighborhood watch volunteer, Ja’Ron Smith was among a group of congressional aides who pulled on hoodies and stood on the steps of the U.S. Capitol in protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott
title: Trump Wants to Derail Sessions. Now Alabama Will Have the Final Say.
description: Tuesday’s runoff election for Senate may finally settle Jeff Sessions’s yearslong standoff with President Trump, as Republicans referee between a native son and a president they admire.
content: ROBERTSDALE, Ala. — For a moment, the whole room was on his side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall and Mihir Zaveri
title: 11-Year-Old and 2 Teenagers Killed in Crash of Cars Doing ‘Doughnuts’
description: Four other teenagers were also injured in the collision, which occurred when the teenage drivers were doing stunts at Floyd Bennett Field, the police said.
content: On a warm Saturday evening, a group of teenagers gathered at Floyd Bennett Field, a decommissioned airfield in southeast Brooklyn, for some summertime antics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and John Ismay
title: 21 People Are Injured in Navy Ship Fire in San Diego
description: A Navy spokesman said that 17 sailors and four civilians were being treated for injuries after a fire and explosion aboard the U.S.S. Bonhomme Richard.
content: At least 21 people were injured when a fire and an explosion broke out Sunday on a U.S. Navy warship that was docked in San Diego, causing heavy damage and posing unique hazards for firefighters, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Immediately Began to Wonder Whether I Was on the Right Train’
description: Confusion over what number Lou Gehrig wore, an outdoor lunch and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: What a Biden Economy Could Look Like
description: Record-breaking infection rates, more economic fallout and Biden’s plan to deal with it.
content: Good morning from the coronavirus time warp, where case numbers go in the wrong direction at a record clip and testing falls short yet again. But at least we have Storm King back! (And Disney World, yikes.) Here’s what you need to know for the week ahead in business and tech news.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin and Elijah Walker
title: Coronavirus Surge, Roger Stone, Summer Gardens: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.25 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘We Didn’t Want to Sit Idle’: A Rush to Meet Pro Sports’ Testing Needs
description: A handful of companies and labs quickly overhauled themselves to fulfill the sudden demand for coronavirus testing from the major American pro leagues.
content: In early March, as the coronavirus was spreading across the United States and testing capacity was already a problem, Bill Phillips had an idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Krajeski
title: The Pathologist: She Confronts the Virus From Inside Nursing Homes
description: Trained as a doctor in Iraq, Lubab al-Quraishi now works on the front lines of America’s Covid-19 crisis, testing older adults for the coronavirus.
content: — Lubab al-Quraishi, a pathology assistant in New Jersey
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Man, 30, Dies After Attending a ‘Covid Party,’ Texas Hospital Says
description: “I thought this was a hoax,” the man told his nurse, a hospital official said.
content: A 30-year-old man who believed the coronavirus was a hoax and attended a “Covid party” died after being infected with the virus, according to a Texas hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.25 Million
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

author: By James Wagner
title: ‘We Didn’t Want to Sit Idle’: A Rush to Meet Pro Sports’ Testing Needs
description: A handful of companies and labs quickly overhauled themselves to fulfill the sudden demand for coronavirus testing from the major American pro leagues.
content: In early March, as the coronavirus was spreading across the United States and testing capacity was already a problem, Bill Phillips had an idea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Marlo, a Rising Atlanta Rapper With Big Connections, Is Shot and Killed at 30
description: A local favorite who came up alongside Lil Baby and Migos, Marlo was found dead after a highway shooting on Saturday night.
content: Rudolph Johnson, the up-and-coming Atlanta rapper known as Marlo, who loomed large among his city’s rap heavyweights even as he remained an underground figure and ambivalent local celebrity, was shot and killed there on Saturday night, the police said. He was 30.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Williams
title: ‘Action Park’ Looks Back in Amusement and Terror
description: In a new memoir, Andy Mulvihill tells the story of the notorious New Jersey adventure land founded by his father.
content: In 1980, when he was 16 years old, Andy Mulvihill stood at the top of a water slide called Cannonball Loop at Action Park, the beloved and notorious New Jersey amusement park founded in 1978 by his father, Gene Mulvihill. The Cannonball Loop included an “improbable” 360-degree vertical turn near the finish. Andy had been enlisted as the first living creature to test the safety of the experience. Previously, “someone had tied off the ankles and sleeves of an old janitorial jumpsuit, stuffed it with sand and fabricated a head out of a plastic grocery bag,” Mulvihill writes in his new book, “Action Park: Fast Times, Wild Rides, and the Untold Story of America’s Most Dangerous Amusement Park.” “The makeshift dummy cleared the loop but emerged decapitated.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Hwaida Saad
title: Bartering Child’s Dress for Food: Life in Lebanon’s Economic Crisis
description: A TV chef abandons unaffordable beef. Blackouts make for sweltering summer nights. Changing money feels like a drug deal: The financial meltdown means daily pain and a blow to a country’s pride.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For three decades, Chef Antoine El Hajj has appeared on television five days a week to help cooks across Lebanon improve their grasp of the culinary arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Aides Undercut Fauci as He Speaks Up on Virus Concerns
description: Administration officials moved to treat the nation’s top infectious disease expert as if he were a warring political rival, releasing a list of what they said were questionable statements he had made.
content: President Trump’s advisers undercut the nation’s top infectious disease expert, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, over the weekend, anonymously providing details to various news outlets about statements he had made early in the coronavirus outbreak that they said were inaccurate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Associated Press
title: Collin Morikawa Is Near-Perfect to Beat Justin Thomas in a Playoff
description: Morikawa made up a three-shot deficit on the final three holes in regulation and beat fifth-ranked Justin Thomas in a three-hole playoff to win the Workday Charity Open.
content: DUBLIN, Ohio — Collin Morikawa figured his tournament was over if he did not make a 5-foot par putt on the 15th hole at Muirfield Village. As it turned out, the fun was just starting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: When Scholars Collaborate With Tech Companies, How Reliable Are the Findings?
description: Uber and Lyft hailed a Cornell paper’s conclusion that their drivers make solid wages. But others have questioned the researchers’ approach.
content: The most contested question in the gig economy may be how much workers earn, since their hourly wages can be widely uneven. Concerns about pay have helped fuel moves in California and New York City to regulate gig-economy companies as if they were more like conventional employers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Graham to Call Mueller to Testify Before Senate Judiciary Committee
description: The announcement is the latest effort by Senate Republicans to press forward with an election-year bid to discredit the Trump-Russia investigation.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Lindsey Graham, Republican of South Carolina and the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, said on Sunday that he would call the former special counsel Robert S. Mueller III to testify before his panel about the investigation of Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election and ties to the Trump campaign.
source.name: The New York Times
